description.text: This is the result of a lot of experimentation with printable clamping mechanisms to hold two surfaces together tightly. This clamp design lets me insert and remove an object (in this case, the reeds for an accordion) and vary the clamping force holding it in place. I put up a detailed writeup on how to design these togs here: http://pocketfactory.org/?p=71, and this is really just a companion thing for that writeup. You're free to print my design, but I put up these designs with the intention of adding another tool to the toolbox of 3D printable mechanisms. Happy printing!

I recommend that you use my design and thinking (see my detailed blog post on designing togs here: http://pocketfactory.org/?p=71) in your own designs, rather than just print out the object that I've shared (unless you really want a reed block for a button accordion). This is more of a mechanism to be used in your own designs than an object in and of itself. If you do print these designs, know that it takes a bunch of force to get the tog into the tog block. I'd insert it partway, and then flip it over and press the thing against the table with the heel of my hand to get the tog all the way in. It's an alarming amount of force, but hey--it works.
Iphone 6 plus maserati case, very nice.

description.text:
I found it very hard to find a 15"x15" picture frame for some art I bought so since I designed one. it has a small batman logo inset just because I could.

the file is 4 6" sides and 4 1.5" corner pieces held together my 3d printed dowel rods
I did have to purchase the plexi and the backer board from hobby lobby and cut them to size. $8 for the plexi and $3 for the backer and I would suggest some model glue or a clear epoxy since the gorilla glue I used did not dry clear.

I printed on a Da Vinci jr (hence the 6" build size)
.2 layer hight
infil @ 30% (not for strength but for the cleaner top layer)
no supports needed

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/faLR9P8f7kZ

Together with an ordinary loose table leg this allows for keeping several rolls at the ready on the K8200 3D-printer.
Fasten it high on the backside with those square nuts and suitable bolts.
(You might want to lower the overlaying profile to make room for the diameter of the rolls.)

DaVinci Jr 1.0

comments.text: I printed out the large cannon. I like it. I tried to load it into 123D Design, because I wanted to tweek it a little but couldn't. I wanted to split it down the middle. But put tabs in the middle to still be able to lock it as one piece. Placing posts on the sides to make these as extra guns for the sides of the tank or in his hands (or for others to use). So Tabbing this cannon using the gun post (hole closer to the open cannon barrel end) on the tank let's the cannon sit a little further back. I'm gonna drill out the other hole for Brawl's hand gun after it finishes printing. I had the foot piece attached and folded the thumb to a side. If there was another hole near the back of the cannon. That kinda gives it a G1 tank cannon attached look. One thing I did not like, was pulling out the support build material in the barrels of the cannon. All in all, you did a good job on this, and look forward to other creations you'll be making.

This is a parametric printable bearing with a two-piece hub that allows the tension on the balls to be adjusted. Tightening nuts against the hub pushes the balls against the outer ring to adjust for printer tolerances and so that it won't become wobbly once its worn in. The two-piece hub also makes it easier to assemble.
The script includes variables for inner diameter, outer diameter, bearing width, ball diameter, and the angle of contact between the balls and the hub/ring. It is designed to be used with vitamin bbs or round beads. All of the pictures are sized to match a 608 bearing (7mm width, 22mm diameter). The bearings are, from left to right, 6mm plastic airsoft bbs with a 3mm shaft, 4.5mm metal bbs with a 6mm shaftt, 4.5mm metal bbs with an 8mm shaft, and 3mm spherical beads with an 8mm shaft.

comments.text: now, when you say round/spherical beads are you referring to printed beads or something else?
comments.author: polymaker

comments.text: I haven't designed printable beads. You could print them, but it's hard to print a decent sphere because of the overhangs on the bottom and the small contact area with the platform. Also, unless you're printing a very large bearing with marble-sized balls, the resolution of our printers would not produce a great bearing. I had another idea that I might develop that uses tapered cylindrical rollers instead of balls, which could be printed (or, without the tapering, could even be clipped pieces of filament). I haven't developed this idea yet, though.
comments.author: polymaker

comments.text: Great idea, clipped pieces of filament would be the perfect size for 608 bearings!

author: mortomr

description.text:
I've created an improved version of this mount that includes ducts to direct the airflow for better cooling.

A dual cooling fan mount for the Robo 3D R1 that moves the fans back out of the way when using a larger hotend. I built this to work with my E3D v5, but there's plenty of clearance so it should work pretty much regardless of what hotend you're running.

This mount is based off of a fan mount designed by Tesseract which served me well for a long time before I decided to upgrade to a dual fan system. I modeled this one from scratch, but the design borrows heavily from Tesseract's original idea.

The mount is designed to work with 40mm or 50mm fans.

The fan mount screws into the right side of the carriage using the two existing holes there. You can either use 3mm screws (that's the way I had Tesseract's mount installed) or if you manage to strip the holes out like I did, you can tap for a #6-32 machine screw which seems to be working perfectly for me.
fan adapter 2x40mm to 50mm

title: Calibration Shapes Tests - 3DPrints 100mm 200mm xy and XYZ towers

description.text:
This is a test to calibrate your print
I used it to test my delta, but you can use also in a Prusa or other 3d printers!
Is a 100mm square a square? A circle is a circle?
Where are the X Y Z towers in a Delta?
Is 1mm line 1 mm?

Control and check:
1 your center
2 10cm diameter Circle
3 A 100mm square
4 Your X and Y points
5 In a DELTA you can see where are XYZ tower!
6 200mm -x +x -y +y points
7 30/60° degree lines

After a print you can measure it and if you find differences you can fix the marlin file!
Fix= (200mm/your real printed 200mm)*(marlin numbers)

title: K300 / J-Head / E3D Hotend Quick Clamp Holder for Rostock Delta Printer

description.text:
Clamp Holder for many Hotends. Made for my K300 highspeed Hotend, but fits any other with 16mm shaft. The distance bolts take lightweight M2.5 screws, or cut a M3 thread. The clamp technique with only one screw allows fast hotend change and hight adjustment, but is sturdy enough to print with 200mm/s+ @ 5.000mm/s acceleration without noticeable overshoots. Preferably printed in PLA, its stiffer than ABS. The distance bolts are 25mm high to fit a 25mm fan.

author: eried

print_settings.Notes:: Design has been made so it should require any extra supports to print.

description.text:
Handbrake

A handbrake to use in driving games. The picture of the assembled design (or the FreeCAD files) should given an idea how everything fits together. Putting it all together inside the small enclosure wasn't that easy.

All parts don't need to be printed. For example, M5 or M6 threaded bars can be used for different "axles" instead. In addition to the printed parts you'll need some M6 threaded bar, M6 nuts, some screws and something for the handbrake lever. I used a piece of 25mm pipe (with holes drilled for the axles). That was from a left over clothes rail.

Original FreeCAD files of the design are included. I didn't use any Assembly module for FreeCAD, so almost all parts are created in the same file.

PCB

A simple PCB for PIC18F2550 and supporting components was designed using Fritzing and ordered from Fritzing Fab. Device is connected to a computer using USB and it presents itself as a USB keyboard or a analog game controller. Device is also powered by its USB connection.

The design was made to fit this PCB, and it barely did. It's not so easy to get the PCB in its place.

Schematic and Fritzing file is also included.

Software

If implemented using the given schematic, only software component required for this project is the PIC firmware written in C. Device can act as a standard USB keyboard or game controller recognized by Windows. So no extra drivers are required.

I haven't finished my firmware yet. I have only made the minimum to read data from device to see that everything works.

title: Clip for Universal Phone Car Mount - used on 2014 Subaru Legacy

description.text:
I really liked the Universal Phone Car Mount by Eckerput, but the vent clip didn't position the phone where I wanted it in my 2014 Subaru Legacy. Instead, I created a clip that fits snugly over the cubby door handle in the middle of the center dash. Where it is positioned, I still have full access to all cubbies and controls. My first version was a square clip and didn't position the phone in an ideal viewing angle. I was able to fix that problem by angling the clip up 15 degrees.

Note: I did edit the original Universal Phone Car Mount design for my own needs. First, I increased the width of the slots to allow my aftermarket cord to fit. I also removed the diamond shaped slots to satisfy my personal tastes. The modified .scad file is included here for anyone to us.

Hi Donarx. Thanks for your comment.
The problem is Exin Castillos' bricks are bigger than Lego bricks, and its studs are also bigger due to thin inner walls. In these special parts the studs are about 1/3 size because the above parts has 1/2 offset. Please look at picture #4 to compare with a 2x1 regular brick.
In Lego, the inner walls of the bricks are more thick, and that special studs would be very very small and fragile.
I will think in another cornices for Lego, like inverted slopes, but without 1/2 offset and that problems

title: Samsung Wireless Charger Stand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
EDIT Check out version 2, it's way better.

I made this for my wife's Samsung Galaxy Note 5, with the wireless fast charger (model EP-PN920). This puck is slightly larger, and a slightly different shape, than the older non-fast version. I couldn't find anything appropriate on Thingiverse, so I made my own in Tinkercad. She wanted something so that she could watch Netflix in bed, while charging, without having to hold it. It also doubles as a nice bedside clock if you turn on daydream in the android display settings. You can set the phone in either portrait or landscape.

The Note 5 is pretty tall, so if you wanted to use this with a smaller phone, I'd strongly suggest dropping the hole section down a few mm (or alternatively, raise the base points of contact). I've noticed with my Galaxy S6 that it's right on the edge of detection in both portrait and landscape.

Here's the Tinkercad link so you can modify it as you please:
https://www.tinkercad.com/things/1kN9UPh1wjZ

EDIT 20160401:
I'm working on version 2 right now. reduced the width, dropped the charger down a few mm to work with more phones. I haven't had a chance to print it, but you can tinker with it here:
www.tinkercad.com/things/9K8pJOggG5B
I'll remix the original when this one is satisfactory, and link it here.

EDIT 20160412:
v2 (w/cover) can now be found here, until I can print it:
https://www.tinkercad.com/things/1iTt6qQjqjq

EDIT 20160414:
v2 can now be found here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1489562

description.text:
A drill press for drilling holes on custom PCB boards.

Made to fit a small drill from eBay, but easily modifiable to work with something else as the drill mount is a separate part. Note that this drill comes with a power adapter that has a US power plug.

UPDATE: That drill has a really bad chuck which makes fast and accurate drilling much harder. I have installed a different one that works great. I recommend using this one (or similar) instead of the small drill. This drill has a proper chuck and drilling PCB's is easy and fast.

Original FreeCAD files included. Assembly made using Assembly2 addon module, but it doesn't have all restrictions on movements defined.

BOM

  • one of each printed parts, except for the two identical drill harnesses (40mm harnesses for the larger drill)
  • base to build on, a piece of wood or table surface (drill two 8mm holes 80mm apart)
  • 2 x 190mm long M8 threaded rod
  • 2 x 90mm long 8mm smooth rod
  • 2 x LM8UU linear ball bearings
  • 1 x about 130mm threaded rod (length of the handle doesn't really matter)
  • 15 x M8 nuts
  • 4 (or more) 8mm washers
  • 2 x compression springs with 8mm inside diameter
  • 2 x about 10mm long M3 bolts
  • 2 or 3 x 3mm screws to attach cover
  • 4 x 3mm screws to attach drill holders
  • 2 x 3mm bolt
  • 2 x 3mm nut

description.text:
The Spector Gadget Fishing Pole is an attachment for the Python Prosthetic hand by Aaron Brown of Axislab 3D.

You can find this hand at:
https://www.youmagine.com/designs/python-utility-hand-alternative-assistive-device

I remember many a day going out with my father to go fishing at a local pond and wanted to design a project that could help disabled kids to enjoy the sport with their parents too.

The idea here is to build a simple fishing pole that can be attached to the Python Prosthetic hand with minimal non-printed parts. I've included an .PDF file for the Assembly Instructions which includes a detailed Bill Of Materials.

enable #enablecreatetime1

One future enhancement that I have been thinking of is trying to add a means to keep the reel from being free wheeling (similar to perhaps how a come-a-long has a gear that turns and a spring loaded catch). Maybe the community has other better ideas on that mechanism? Thanks.

And again sanding.
Painted the model with hammer effect gold colored paint.

title: Z Extensions for Wanhao Duplicator i3, Cocoon Create, and Maker Select

description.text:
This mod compliments the Z Braces and gives the printer an additional 37mm of clearance on the X Crossbeam.

The manufacturer rated the Z axis to be 180mm but the poor clearance to cables and the extruder meant that only around 143mm was usable. Pushing past this height was not without the risk of failed prints (skipped steps), mechanical damage, electrical short circuit, and the chance of fire.

Optional part to hang the scraper that comes with these printers, it can be printed for left or right sides, or it can be printed for both sides or none.

Print one each of a left and right part (1xL & 1xR), two parts only.

Things to buy:
8x M3 x 10mm screws
4x M3 Nyloc nuts

Z Braces may be found at:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:921948

If you like these mods, and you'd like to fuel even more of them, please send beer coupons to:
https://www.paypal.me/azza68

If you're looking for a filament feeder that woks well with the Di3, then try this:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1672349
Filament feeder for Wanhao Duplicator i3, Cocoon Create, and Maker Select

PLEASE NOTE
This mod does not work with the very first batches of the WanHao branded printers.
It also may not work on the "Powerspec I3 Plus" models (Please see "Comments" section for tips on designing your own or modding this mod.)
If the spool holder cannot be mounted on top of the beam, using the factory drilled holes, this mod is not for you.
TTBOMK The beam change was made, in factory, on the 15 June 2015 so only very early Di3 models are affected.
If you do have a very early/beta model, you can still use the parts as tool holders by using the top two screw holes only. You just wont get any height advantage.

Printer:

WanHao Di3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

3 shells, or around 1.2mm thick walls.

PLA or your favourite hard plastic.

1.

Turn on the printer.
Zero the Z axis.
Move the printer to Z=10mm

Turn off the printer and disconnect the power.

2.

Remove the spool holder, if fitted.
Undo the 4 screws of each top bracket (of the Z braces).
Undo the 2 screws on each side of the top frame, X crossbeam.

Carefully remove the X crossbeam.

Take care that the smooth rod retainers and their brackets do not fall off.

Replace the lower two screws, on each side, as soon as possible; to keep things aligned and stop them from flopping around.

3.

Replace the X crossbeam with the bottom screw holes aligned with the top of the Z braces.
Re-affix the Z braces using their old screws.

Do not tighten the screws at this time.

4.

Affix the new Z Extensions to each side of the towers, using the 10mm long M3 screws and Nyloc nuts (on the lower 2 holes).

Do not tighten the screws at this time.

5.

With all screws fitted but loose enough to allow movement by slight force.

Turn on the printer.
Zero the Z axis.
Move the printer to Z=160mm

Turn off the printer and disconnect the power.

6.

Whilst applying a downwards force to the smooth rod retainers, tighten the screws on the Z braces.

Tighten the screws on the Z extensions, the metal parts should sit flush against the new plastic parts.

Refit the spool holder.

7.

Turn on the printer.

Check for full and free moment of the Z axis.

8.

Resume printing like never before; with the full 180mm of Z available for use.

comments.text: I did think about doing just that, but applied the KISS principle and decided not to; the Z braces make the frame rock-solid and redesigning them for this mod would not be worth any possible gain (which would be minimal if even quantifiable). I have picked the printer up by the extended crossbeam and there was no change in the bed to head levelling. So I really don't think there would be any benefit for the extra work... plus it gives us four more holes to do something else with... so the saved effort can be used elsewhere. :-)

A dimensionally correct UK plug to use as a template in your designs.

Use as a template. Whilst it will probably print on a 3D printer without any issues it would be of limited use other than blocking a plug socket much like the socket safety covers that are sold to prevent children sticking objects into the holes. The socket safety covers have been proven to cause more harm than good. 99% of all UK sockets sold in the past 60 years have inbuilt safety mechanisms that prevent the live and neutral holes from being exposed without a plug been inserted so these covers are not required. See http://www.fatallyflawed.org.uk for more information about this.

title: LED Power Supply Mount for Misumi 2020 extrusion

description.text:
This is a part that fits what I believe is a standard LED power supply. Mine has two sets of 3mm holes on the side spaced 25mm on center apart. That makes the socket head cap screws I used interfere with the 2020 extrusion so I created the part to have the heads countersunk. The part isn't 100% symmetric because the power supply isn't, but I probably should have just left it symmetric because it's not noticeable and slightly throws off the angle of the power supply compared to the extrusion (probably less than 1 degree).

It's designed for 3mm socket head cap screws, two were about M3 x 8 or 10, the other was M3 x 35 and has a nyloc nut securing it. The long screw didn't turn out to be necessary since the part fits pretty tightly on the extrusion, but I put it there on the odd chance I want to transport my printer in a rough way.

Printer:

Eclips3D Printer (CoreXY)

Rafts:

No

No

20-30%

Notes:

I printed this in ESun natural PETG for strength and so it's not brittle like PLA gets. But anything would probably work. The holes are slightly oversized to allow for some screw movement/misalignment and printer issues, but may still require post-print cleanup. Print two for a single power supply. Could be used for other things too presumably.

description.text:
Wanhao I3 Duplicator (may fit other models too) adjustable belt tensioner. Due to the fact that I could not print the original design for the belt teeth correctly. Could not slide fit the belt in the slots! I changed/updated the just slide in and hold for both sides of the belt to slide in (wider slot) and clamp it with 3X5 mm hexagon setscrews in both parts. The two M4 holes to fit the main part to the bearing block need to be drilled to perfection with M4. Do not forget to tap the holes in the bearing block with M4 too as they are not from the factory..

Needed parts to fix:
4 x M3 x 5 mm hexagon set screw (uses 1.5 mm hexagon tool)
1 x M3 lock nut
1 x M3 X 30 mm hexagon screw

2 x M4 (originals belt fixation screws)

Pictures show 1st stage prototype.
STL print file has extra set screw hole and bridge part for durability.

Mounting plate for Shure BLX4 wireless lavalier mic receiver. No modification to your equipment.
Stays secure even if camera is tilting. Fits hotshoe for most DSLR.
Holes on bottom of Shure receiver fit over plate posts.
Cable guide to keep wires neat.

1) Print
STL are ready for any printer with at least 3.5" x 3.5" print area. 2) Align
Left: Wire hook goes toward left. Posts point up.
Middle: Turn upside down so 4 holes point down and are nearest to you.
Right: Posts point up.
Hotshoe: Flat tall edge is nearest to you. Posts point up. 3) Glue
Put glue in overlapping parts of plates and press to fit.
Put glue in 4 holes in middle plate and press in hotshoe.

print_settings.Notes:: I printed this with several print bed setups (glass+hair spray, glue stick, buildtak).  The best results were achieved via the buildtak, hands down.  Orientation is critical to the print, i would highly recommend to print the part in the vertical orientation and print inside to outer layers.  note that this will eat up a pen cap as it is captured in order to hold the pen in place...as a heads up, there still needs to be some tweaking to get the pen cap to fit better....its a bit tight as it is now.  I just got some more caps in ($10 a piece from neopen) and plan to update the fit so its not as tight...

title: Neo Smartpen N2 Professional Notebook Clip (Moleskine)

description.text: This is a pen holder for the Neo Smartpen N2 (http://shop.neosmartpen.com/collections/frontpage). This allows one to attach the pen to the N professional notebook (http://shop.neosmartpen.com/collections/n-notebook/products/n-notebook-5) as designed, but shimming or modification can be made to allow it to be attached to any compatible notebook. This also provides a self standing dock (looks nice) for charging and also has 2 slots for additional refills. As a heads up, the applied design is done using vinyl and a cricut explorer air cutting machine (https://shop.cricut.com/en_us/machines/cricut-explore-air.html?gclid=Cj0KEQjw5ti3BRD89aDFnb3SxPcBEiQAssnp0rjv0mluiTTbxTTuGrxfUm5l4GxpoR62-pjpLh72BxAaAlpz8P8HAQ).

Printer:

Flaahforge Creator Pro

Infill:

hex

Notes:

I printed this with several print bed setups (glass+hair spray, glue stick, buildtak). The best results were achieved via the buildtak, hands down. Orientation is critical to the print, i would highly recommend to print the part in the vertical orientation and print inside to outer layers. note that this will eat up a pen cap as it is captured in order to hold the pen in place...as a heads up, there still needs to be some tweaking to get the pen cap to fit better....its a bit tight as it is now. I just got some more caps in ($10 a piece from neopen) and plan to update the fit so its not as tight...

Follow the link and copy to your Onshape workspace (you need to sign up: https://cad.onshape.com/signup/[email protected]

Once in your workspace, you can fully edit everything including any feature i may have used to create the model...very handy and much more versatile than scaling or boolean operations.

description.text: made this for my friend enjoy

This is a Raspberry Pi based stereo bookshelf setup. The Volumio (https://volumio.org/) Raspberry Pi distribution is used to manage music playback. A 16x2 LCD screen is connected to the GPIO of the Raspberry Pi in order to display the current artist and song. Music is controlled using a web interface.

Parts Required:
Raspberry Pi B+
Lepai (Lepy) LP-2020A 2020 Class-T Hi-Fi Audio Mini Amplifier (found on Amazon for under $30)
LCD Screen- 16x2 HD44780 5V (https://www.dipmicro.com/store/LCD1602B-GEN)
8x M3x10 screws
4x M2.5x5 screws

Raspberry Pi and LCD Screen.

title: Roach Trap...Reusable trap to catch and kill cockroaches
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
It's safe to say most people have a dislike ( ...hate ... are scared) of cockroaches. If you're in this group and have the odd roach problem then this could be your solution.

We were regularly getting cockroaches sheltering in our letterbox. All too often this meant you carried them inside the house hidden amongst the mail... particularly the junk mail. Sprays and baits inside the letterbox never seemed to have any effect (...although that's not to say they didn't wander away to die elsewhere?)

Baits aren't cheap and the idea of spray coated mail didn't exactly appeal either so I developed a small reusable 'Roach Trap' that has proven to be effective at catching cockroaches. How you deal with them after they are trapped inside is up to you... spray insect spray up the entry, drop it all into water until they drown... or just open the end sliding door, knock them out and squash them. However you decide to deal with them at least you have a corpse so you know there's one less roach to annoy you.

This is a simple print with no support required and they don't use a lot of filament. Print with translucent filament so you can see through the thin walls and see if there's a roach inside ( ...you can shake it and they often start scuttling around). Use 2 shells but high infill (50%) to make sure the walls are almost solid and strong... after all this is a Roach prison.

In operation, attracted to the trap by a tempting smell, there is a ramp that is easy for a cockroach to climb. At the end of the ramp there is a drop into the trap... they drop in only to discover there is no way out. The ramp is a tunnel / tube that has no walls / surfaces leading to the entrance that a cockroach can climb to escape. At the other end of the trap is a small sliding door. This is used to insert the bait and... remove trapped Roaches.

To attract cockroaches to your trap use something like a small piece of banana and banana peel inside the trap through the sliding door. Having searched online for things that attract cockroaches sweet/fragrant things like this seem to work well... just don't put too much as a cockroach could potentially climb over and get out.

This is a really simple little solution to an annoying problem most people have to deal with at times. The 'Roach Trap' is reusable, doesn't need any expansive baits or sprays so can save you money and the concern about poisons on surfaces around your home.

Give it a go... print one... catch a few and you'll print more!

To the best of my knowledge there is no similar commercial solution remotely like this.... at standard size they 'Roach Trap' measures 32mm (W) x 57.5mm (L) x 22mm (H). This works well with the Roaches in our area up to about 25mm long. Got bigger Roaches... just scale it up uniformly and it should work just as well. Scaling down is not recommended.

Please refer to the images and print instructions for additional information. Your Roach Trap must be used the correct way up to trap Roaches!

Note: If you like this check out the rest of my practical and fun designs.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Yes

No

Resolution:

0.20mm / Standard in translucent PLA

Infill:

2 Shells / 50% infill to ensure the thin walls are strong

Notes:

Recommend 2 shells and 50% infill to make the 'Roach Trap' strong as it has thin walls. Although not essential, using translucent filament lets you see in side adequately to see if you've caught a Roach.

Raft is recommended to ensure a good build from a solid base. This is due to the thin walls which do not give it a big contact area with the build plate (it builds up on it's end due to the internal shaping).

Just add you bait to attact Roaches!

Try and find what attracts your particular type of cockroach. We've found a small piece of banana and banana skin works very effectively. They can smell it from quite some distance. Place small pieces inside the trap through the sliding door... slide the door closed and put your trap in an area your Roaches regularly visit.

IMPORTANT: Your Roach Trap must be used the correct way up to trap Roaches!

Once you've trapped a Roach you can spray into the trap to kill it, submerge it in water to drown them (although maybe Roaches can live under water a long time?) or just open the sliding door, knock them down/out and squash them.

title: Bearing block for 8 mm shaft, X,Y,Z axes, using 693zz bearings at 120 degrees

description.text:
You may use this bearing blocks to replace linear bearings on X, Y, Z axes of your Prusa I3 from Sunhokey. The distance between the shaft and the plate to which you attach the block is 7 mm, like in stock linear bearing. You need two blocks on each shaft.

If you use it on Z it would be perfect.
If you use it on Y it will leave you exactly the same space for building along the Y axis.
For X-axis I would use the block posted below so far.

This is the proposal to replace http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1424346 and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1438544

Bearings to use: 693.
Screws to use: M3x16 screws which came with your printer, help me to find DIN.
Self-locking nuts to use: DIN 985. Regular nuts are also OK.

Notes:

Not printed yet. If you will - let me know if holes for M3 and M4 screws are too wide or too narrow.

A very simple Raspberry Pi 2 / 3 Enclosure. It uses 4 screws with countersinks in the bottom plate. This is about as simple as you can get for a full Pi enclosure.

Screws should be M2.5 to match the mounting holes for the board, or #2's should work as well.

Parts have been printed and test fitted against multiple Pi2 boards. Recommended print settings with PLA: .2mm height, 100% infill, no raft, no supports. If your printer is pretty well dialed in, you shouldn't need supports for the short overhangs. Part is designed to lose 1-3 layers and still fit well.

Providing the original 3DM source file, so feel free to adapt to your needs.

This thing is a 4 element 9dBi directional yagi antenna designed for FPV flying. It has been tuned to the 1280MHz frequency. It is built using 2mm pushrods and a piece of coax cable with an SMA connector.

The antenna dimensions have come from IBCrazy's thread on RCGroups - http://www.rcgroups.com/forums/showthread.php?t=1266148

The 3D Sketchup file is included. This can be used as a temple to create a yagi tuned to a different frequency.

Push Rods 2mm (see lengths required below) - http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__28821__Metal_Push_Rods_M2xL300_2pcs_set_.html

SMA RG316 Coaxial Cable x 30cm - http://www.ebay.com.au/itm/10-15-30-50cm-1m-SMA-Male-Jack-to-Female-Nut-Extension-RF-Pigtail-Cable-RG316-/191490074919?var=&hash=item2c95b2a927:m:m7wcOaCmV65T-xtusEKsghQ

Cable Ties x 2 - http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__46892__Cable_Ties_160_x_2_5mm_Black_100pcs_.html

1. Cut 5 pieces of 2mm push rods to the following lengths - 112.8mm, 53.0mm (x2), 104.1mm & 95.5mm.
  2. Insert the push rods into the 3D printed housing. 112.8mm into the 1st slot, 53.0mm x 2 into the second slot upper and lower, 104.1mm into the 3rd slot & 95.5mm into the 4th slot.
  3. Remove 8mm from the coax cable outer plastic sheath.
  4. Fold back the woven ground shield and twist together.
  5. Remove 5mm from the inner conductor shield.
  6. Tin the ground shield and inner conductor.
  7. Insert the coax cable into the slot. Align the ground shield with the lower push rod and the inner conductor with the upper push rod.
  8. Add cable ties to hold the coax cable in place.
  9. Solder the coax cable inner conductor and ground shield to the push rods.

title: Printrbot Metal Simple Spool holder and Z-rod Stabilizer

description.text: You may have noticed when moving the z axis at top speed, the z drive rod can make noise from whipping around. I found somebody had a z-axis stabilizer and I like that, and used it for a while. Then I optimized the design to use less material as I'm wont to do. I also designed a variety of spool holders, all of which work good, the last of them being quite optimized for that type of design. Then I got to thinking - why not combine both into one part? So I did. Best of my designs so far, and uses little material. This will work with a wide variety of spool sizes, and clears the z stepper as it goes up.

description.text:
Inspired by a push drill and bevel gear assembly i saw on thingiverse. I wondered if i could make a lightweight hand-cranked version of my vintage hand drill. The result is a small hobby drill which takes 2mm to 6mm bits. Smooth running because it uses bearings and the tolerances are fine. this is a tough little drill.

you'll need
2x M3 25mm bolts, washers & nylock nuts.
6x 14mm x 5mm bearings (inner 8mm).

Main body should be at least 50% infill, and all pins, spindles, screws, gears and chuck parts need to be 100%. The handles 20%.
Support used on both spindles and main body.

PLA prefered as its easy to lubricate with 3in1 oil or silicon grease.
ABS can be greased with "Super Lube" silicon grease only, else it disintegrates.

description.text:
This Thing is a mounting bracket for fixing a webcam to a flatscreen, table, desklamp, or whatever object it needs to be fixed to.

Clamping of objects up to 45mm is possible, although it is advisable to put a rubber pad on the stationary clamp side, to prevent it from slipping off its base, so depending on what you use the maximum clamping thickness gets reduced more or less.
The Mount offers two degrees of freedom for adjusting the camera.

For the moment I have uploaded a draft of a sleeve to hold a Microsoft LiveCam Studio webcam, which can be held in Place by clamping the sleeve with a M5x35-40 bolt and a fitting nut. In my case the camera fits the sleeve so snugly I didn't need a retaining bolt.
The sleeve might get optimized in the near future, I designed it while half asleep and it could be better, but it works for now. The Button on top of the cam is covered by the sleeve (in the current version), although there are holes for the mic.

I intend to add mounts for other things like flashlights or other cams in the future, if I deem them useful.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Modified Huxley

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

AFAP

Infill:

60%

Notes:

Printed in PLA with 0.4mm layers for the C-Clamp and Camera Sleeve,
0.25 for the small parts.

Everything should already be oriented the best way for FDM printing

Printed Parts:

Print each part once. Or n-times , if you need to mount n Webcams (n should, ideally, be a natural number here - otherwise things might get complicated.)

Vitamins for one complete mount:

2x M8 Nut
1x M8x65 Bolt (Shorter is okay, if you only need to clamp to thick objects)
1x M5x25 Bolt (For fixing cam sleeve to swivel)
1x M5x35-40 Bolt (For retaining camera in sleeve)
4x M5 Washers
2x M5 Nuts (Flat ones are okay)
4x M3x6-8 DIN912 hex socket bolts
4x M3 Nut

Assembly:

The assembly should hopefully be pretty self explanatory. Well, I'll explain anyway.

  1. Mount the swivel on the C-Bracket using the swivel-retainer plate and the M3 screws. If your printer is better calibrated than mine, and the swivel has so much play that it won't stay in the desired position, put a thin spacer under the swivel knob (folded paper, cardboard, washer...). Mine works just fine without any post-print cleaning of the parts.
  2. Press or glue one M8 nut into the clamp pad.
  3. Insert the other M8 nut into the hexagonal recess in the bottom of the C-Clamp (It will be held in pace by the clamping force, but if you like you can glue it anyway) and screw in the M8 bolt to secure it.
  4. Screw the pad onto the M8 Bolt until the bolt doesn't go any further in.
  5. Mount the Cam sleeve using the M5x25 bolt, M5 nut and two washers (under the head and the nut)
  6. Slide the clamp in the sleeve.
  7. (Optional) Put the remaining M5 bolt through the holes in the sleeve and carefully clamp the camera using the remaining Nut and washers.

title: Diamond Hotend Mounting With Extra Attach Points

description.text:
Remixed:

  • Moved blower attach block away from the screw path. Now one may use a nut to mount something else, like an LED PCB, under the top fan.
  • Added a secondary attach point for a future height probe.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3 Improved for Lasercut

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Printed in black ABS at 230 degrees celsius. Used 4 raft layers, 10mm brim, hairspray, heated bed to 110 degrees, and a "build chamber" for extra adhesion. By "build chamber" I mean an old wardrobe keeping heat inside and cold drafts out.

• Removed bulk raft by peeling.
  • Taped a sandpaper to a flat surface.
  • Sanded away remaining raft, leaving top fan mount flat.
  • Sanded all mounting surfaces flat (blower, probe and back mounting plate).
  • Inserted all 6 trapped nuts BEFORE mounting the hotend.
  • Used zip-ties to hold the back of the top fan, but screws to hold the front. I intent to mount a LED lighting PCB there later.

... is here.
The white parts in the pictures are from the original thing, check the "Remixed From" link. I plan on changing them by:

  • Move the mount holes of the fan support plate to the right position.
  • Add some clearance between the mounting plate and the fan, so it can accommodate the M3x8 screw heads under the fan, and I can remove the washers.
  • Clear the neck-down where the fan nozzle attaches to the fan. It gets really narrow there and, while I haven't tested yet, I believe it would reduce the airflow. I plan on making it a thin wall (<1mm) and seal the connection with electrical tape from outside.
  • Critical: Print in black to match. :-)

title: Not So Itty Bitty Belted Extruder

description.text:
This is a remix of clough42's Itty Bitty Belted Extruder using a Nema17 rather then a Nema14 motor. All other parts are carried over. I used his build instructions as these are very similar

The recess in the bottom is designed for a e3d v6 hot end. I do not have one yet but will this week. Until I test fit it I'm marking this as a work in progress. The images are from the first printing I did where I forgot to include this recess.

Its designed to work with 1.75 filament. I added an additional model for .3 filament but as I do not run this I will not be able to test it.

I designed a mount to work with a V-Slot mini Gantry : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1449705.

I did not change the geometry from the Itty Bitty Belted Extruder so any mount that would work for that should work for this.

I designed it so the same 188gt2 belt can be used. It's tight but fits. I extend the adjusters so any belt from 188 to 200 should work.

You can read more about the Itty Bitty Belted Extruder here : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:389105

Added two additional versions :

Not_So_Itty_Bitty_Belted_Extruder_With_Top_Chain_Mount.stl - Provides mounting locations for a cable chain.
Not_So_Itty_Bitty_Belted_Extruder_30.stl - 3mm filament

I have an alternate guidler that I'm running now here : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1460827

https://youtu.be/RPqzVzOpp0M

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Folgertech i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Support material is needed for this to print properly.

To complete this, you will need:

  • Three 608 bearings ( http://amzn.to/1TbNpqh )
  • An 8mm diameter 18-20mm pin for the guidler bearing
  • two 45-60mm M3 screws ( http://amzn.to/1UQgs3I, http://amzn.to/1XVF8WH)
  • Three 10mm M3 screws ( http://amzn.to/1UlAseL )
  • Eight M3 washers ( http://amzn.to/1UQgw3t )
  • Two M3 nuts ( http://amzn.to/1UQgysd )
  • Two extruder springs ( I used pen springs ) but these faucet spring work great as well ( http://amzn.to/1RTEqee )
  • A hobbed bolt with two jam nuts: http://clough42.com/go/product/hobbed-extruder-bolt/
  • A NEMA 17 motor: ( http://amzn.to/1XVFvR9 )
  • A drive kit: http://clough42.com/go/product/itty-bitty-belted-extruder-drive-kit/
    -- A 20-tooth GT2 pulley for the motor
    -- A 188-2GT belt (GT2, 2mm pitch, 6mm width, 188mm/94 tooth closed loop)

Instructions:

After printing, snap off the support structures and clean out the bridging from the screw and hobbed bolt holes.
Press in the hobbed bolt bearings and make sure they turn freely.
Install the motor with three M3x10 screws (two washers on each bolt). Leave the screws loose for now.
Install the hobbed bolt with the 1mm spacer under the head and the 2mm spacer behind the large pulley. Adjust the tension and lock with a jam nut.
Assemble and install the guidler.
Install the motor pulley and belt, adjust the belt tension and lock down the motor screws. You can reach the third motor screw through one of the pulley holes using a ball-end driver.
I'm using the Clough42 custom milled bolt with 1/16 microstepping and a steps-per-unit value of 644.2 configured in Marlin. With this configuration, I'm having no trouble with 25mm/s retraction.

title: ArduCam Rasperry Pi Camera Mount with LED Ring and 2020 Interface

description.text:
This camera mount was designed to be used with the ArduCam Raspberry Pi camera module, which has a slightly different footprint than the Raspberry Pi camera module. It also includes an interface for a 40 mm LED ring (look for 40 mm "Angel Eyes HeadLight Halo Ring" on eBay), and an interface for attaching to a 2020 rail.

Incidentally, the ArduCam with the M12x0.5 Mount Lens has an adjustable focus and great optical performance, making it very suitable for a 3D printer webcam with an OctoPrint setup.

(Update: I've just added a simple LED schematic I used to connect the Raspberry Pi to the LED. See comments section for instructions on how to configure Octoprint.)

comments.text: Can you tell me how to hook up the light on the raspberry pi and how you turn the lignt on/off?
comments.author: Protosag3D

comments.text: Also, if you are using Octoprint, then you can make a few simple mods to add a menu to the web interface which allows you to turn the light on and off.
comments.author: Protosag3D

comments.text: I used a 2N2222 NPN transistor (others NPN transistors such as 2N3904 will also work).  Connect the V+ (red wire) on the LED ring to 12V (from your printer power supply), and the V- (black wire) to the transistor collector.  Connect the transistor emitter to ground.  Then connect the transistor gate to the RPI GPIO21 via a 500 ohm resistor, and the gate to ground via a 10K resistor.
comments.author: Protosag3D

comments.text:
Can I use this:
https://www.amazon.ca/Dovewill-XL6009-Adjustable-Converter-Voltage/dp/B078LL2FNH/ref=sr_1_11?s=electronics&ie=UTF8&qid=1514654680&sr=1-11&keywords=xl6009
comments.author: elkayem

comments.text: Yes, but make sure your RPI power supply has plenty of headroom.  A 2.5A power supply should be sufficient.  Keep in mind that  the LED current of 75 mA at 12V will mean your boost converter may be drawing over 200 mA at 5V.  I think that option should be fine if you can't easily access 12V directly from your printer.

comments.text: I don't know if it is normal. I set this up a while ago, and from what I can tell, Octoprint has changed a bit. My config.yaml file is still there. On the other hand, my octoprint.init no longer includes the instruction to initialize the GPIO. I removed that part of the instructions from my previous comment. I suggest going to https://github.com/foosel/OctoPrint/wiki/Controlling-a-relay-board-from-your-RPi for the latest on how to control the GPIO pins from Octoprint, and head over to their forum to ask questions if you get stuck.

description.text:
Easter Grass for your Easter baskets, eggs, etc.

I was just learning OpenSCAD and this was a simple first program:

for ( x = [0:5:150] ) {
translate([x,0,0]) cube([2,150,.2]);
}

Export as STL and done! It is good for testing how level your bed is also.

The egg in the picture is from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:737632 so I want to give them credit.

author: marcforsyth1988

description.text:
I have an Apple Watch and thought that it would be quite handy for navigating the streets via scooter using my maps application. The problem is, there's too much of a delay between the phone and the watch for it to be effective. By the time I am notified it's time to turn, it's already behind me! You can only imagine how frustrating (and dangerous) this must be on the highways!

To remedy this problem, I modified my iPhone 5s VR head mount viewer bracket to take bungee cable hooks at all four corners and voila! Here's the result. Handy, eh? Keep it slow and watch out for potholes though.

If you found this useful, please make sure you share a picture (it makes my day each time someone prints something I designed) and be sure to peruse my other submissions which are almost as varied as they are many:

http://www.thingiverse.com/3E8/designs

Enjoy!

author: mnye75

title: Maglite XL50 flashlight clip for gun sight rail

description.text:
My son and his friends like to shoot at each other with air-soft guns, including day and night battles. For the night battles my son wanted to mount a flashlight on his gun, so we spent about 20 minutes designing this clip on sketchup.
This clip will hold a Maglite XL-50 LED flashlight on any MIL-STD-1913 sight rail. The clip grabs the rail tightly and doesn't slide without applying a lot of force, and it holds the flashlight with a tight grip as well.

I printed this one with generic transparent ABS filament because I didn't have any black filament handy. It shows up better in the pictures this way, anyway. 0.2mm layers, no raft, no brim, no support material, 25% infill, avoid crossing perimeters, 0.5mm retraction on layer change.
The pictures show the clip as it came off the printer- no clean up necessary!
I failed to save the sketchup file for this one! Sorry!
